Award.AwardTitle: Modeling of Mosquitoes Carrying Transgenes or Genetically Modified Bacteria in Preventing the Transmission of Mosquito-Borne Diseases
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator develops various mathematical models for mosquito populations and disease transmission dynamics in this project. This includes models for transgenic mosquitoes, which are resistant to infection by mosquito-borne diseases, and have distinct fitnesses, some of which have advantages over the others. Combined epidemic models are used to study the interactive dynamics of the mosquitoes, characterizing the fact that transgenic mosquitoes have a selective advantage over non-transgenic mosquitoes, and to investigate the effects of transgenic mosquitoes on the disease transmissions. Modeling of transgenic mosquitoes with various genes or strains, as well as modeling of two-sex mosquito populations including both males and females, is also part of this project. All models start with simpler forms, and gradually include more complex structures to better describe the underlying biology. Within each model category, the investigator determines different formulas for the birth and death functions and the contact rates, which facilitates the ability to connect the modelling with real data. With the population models for the mosquitoes well established, various epidemic models for both human and mosquito populations will be incorporated to study the transmission dynamics of the mosquito-borne diseases. The investigator also focuses on modeling of the newly developed paratransgenic technique, which attempts to eliminate a pathogen from mosquito populations through transgenesis of a symbiont, i.e., a genetically modified bacterium, that prevents the mosquitoes from transmitting the pathogen. The dynamics of horizontal bacteria transmission, as well as vertical transmission between mosquitoes, and their effects on the disease transmissions are investigated. The goal is to understand the complexity of the dynamics of the interacting wild mosquitoes and the mosquitoes carrying transgenes or genetically modified bacteria, and predict the impact of releasing the modified mosquitoes. Analysis and numerical simulation is combined to study qualitative and quantitative features of the models, including existence and stability of equilibria, existence of periodic and aperiodic oscillations through bifurcations, and chaotic behavior and transient dynamics. Model parameters are estimated or derived from real biological data and the mathematical analysis of the models covers all parameter regions.

New developments in biology allow researchers to genetically alter mosquitoes so that they are resistant to malaria infection or other mosquito-borne diseases, such as dengue fever and West Nile virus. A more recently developed new paratransgenic approach generates mosquitoes carrying genetically modifies bacteria that impairs in the transmission of pathogens in mosquitoes. The mosquito-borne diseases are transmitted between humans by blood-feeding mosquitoes, and their spread and control have been major concerns for public health. The introduction of modified mosquitoes into wild mosquito populations could be an effective measure in controlling mosquito-borne diseases. To explore this possibility, the investigator, in collaboration with biologists, develops and analyzes mathematical models that represent the population dynamics of wild and transgenic mosquitoes. The models account for the spread of transgenes or genetically modified bacteria through the mosquito population over multiple generations, and predict the impact on the disease transmissions. They help answer such questions as how effectively mosquitoes carrying transgenes or modified bacteria would be able to compete for partners with their wild counterparts, how long it would take for a new resistance gene or bacterium to penetrate the mosquito population, and how effective it would be in preventing the spread of the diseases. In this way, the results of the project can provide useful guidance for public health measures and for disease prevention strategies.

Institution.Name: University of Alabama in Huntsville
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA IN HUNTSVILLE, THE

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
To prevent the transmissions of  mosquito-borne, an effective way is to control mosquitoes. Development of transgenic mosquitoes that are resistant to malaria or dengue, the paratransgenic approach in the generation of transgenic mosquitoes impaired in the transmission of pathogens, and the sterile insect technique used to reduce or eradicate wild mosquitoes, all have provided a new and effective weapon against these diseases. While these new approaches are promising, moving laboratory advances to the field is a major challenge, and many questions have to be answered before such techniques are implemented.
To this end, we formulated mathematical models for the interactive dynamics of wild mosquitoes and transgenic, paratransgenic, or sterile mosquitoes, respectively. In these models, the mosquito populations are assumed either homogeneous without metamorphic stages distinguished or heterogeneous where their stages are included. We also formulated several models for the transmission dynamics of malaria some of which have incorporated the interactive dynamics of wild and transgenic, paratransgenic, or sterile mosquitoes.
In the models for interactive wild and transgenic mosquitoes, we assumed the transgenes are either dominate or recessive. We showed that transgenic mosquitoes can survive only if the total death-adjusted number of offspring with transgenes through heterogeneous matings exceeds that of offspring with no transgenes produced by wild mosquitoes, or there are too many wild offspring causing oscillations in the wild mosquito population. On the other hand, even if the transgenes are recessive, they can still drive wild mosquitoes to extinct. Therefore, dominate transgenes may not necessarily have advantage over recessive transgenes.
In our models for interactive wild and paratransgenic mosquitoes, we assumed that the transmission of the genetically-modified bacteria can be vertically and horizontally. By our investigations, we found out that while the vertical transmission plays an important role in changing the wild mosquitoes to carrying transgenic bacteria, the horizontal transmission makes a clear picture that it can drive the wild mosquitoes to extinct.
We worked on models for interactive wild and sterile mosquitoes more intensively in the last two years. The models were assumed to be either homogeneous or heterogeneous. We considered different strategies for the releases of sterile mosquitoes where the releases are constant, proportional to the size of wild mosquito population, or of Holling II type such that the releases are proportional to the size of wild mosquitos as the size is small, but saturated as the size is sufficiently large. We performed mathematical analysis and numerical simulations for these models. We derived explicit formulas for the threshold release values which determine whether wild mosquitoes can be eliminated. We found out that while the constant releases can lead wild mosquitoes to approaching zero more robustly, it has economic disadvantage that sterile mosquitoes are still released even the size of the wild mosquitoes is near zero. In contrast, the strategy with the releases proportional to the wild mosquito population size can lead both wild and sterile mosquitoes to approaching zero. Thus, it has economic advantage particularly when the wild mosquito population size is small. However, if the wild mosquito population size is significantly large, the amount of the releases needs to be large too which shows its disadvantage economically. As a compromise, the strategy with the release function of the form of Holling-II type is able to gain the advantage of the constant releases but keep the releases more economically optimal.
Meanwhile, as we performed compete analysis for the models with stage structure, it shows that the model dynamics are similar to the simplifier homogeneous models without stage structure. Realizing our fundamental goals are to incorporate the sterile mosquitoes into the disease transmission models, we formulated new models without stage structure, but the development of the mosquito aquatic stages is included. Our analysis shows that all dynamical features of the stage-structured models are kept. Thus these models will be used for the disease transmission models in our future investigations.
Sponsored by this award, we also worked on the models with impulsive releases, where the releases are assumed periodical and impulsive. We considered either the releases are independent or dependent on the current abundance of wild or sterile mosquitoes such that sterile mosquitoes are not released until the size of the wild mosquitoes reaches a preset value or the amount of the sterile mosquitoes has dropped to a preset level. For the former case, the control measures for the releases are the amount of sterile mosquitoes released and the period of the impulsive releases, that is, the time interval between two releases. The wild mosquitoes can be wiped out or the two types of mosquitoes coexist based the thresholds determined from our model analysis. In the latter case, however, the goal is not to eradicate but reduce the wild mosquito size. This is more appropriate in the situation available resources are limited.

 


Last Modified: 11/18/2016
Modified by: Jia Li
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: To prevent the transmissions of mosquito-borne, an effective way is to control mosquitoes. Development of transgenic mosquitoes that are resistant to malaria or dengue, the paratransgenic approach in the generation of transgenic mosquitoes impaired in the transmission of pathogens, and the sterile insect technique used to reduce or eradicate wild mosquitoes, all have provided a new and effective weapon against these diseases. While these new approaches are promising, moving laboratory advances to the field is a major challenge, and many questions have to be answered before such techniques are implemented. To this end, we formulated mathematical models for the interactive dynamics of wild mosquitoes and transgenic, paratransgenic, or sterile mosquitoes, respectively. In these models, the mosquito populations are assumed either homogeneous without metamorphic stages distinguished or heterogeneous where their stages are included. We also formulated several models for the transmission dynamics of malaria some of which have incorporated the interactive dynamics of wild and transgenic, paratransgenic, or sterile mosquitoes. In the models for interactive wild and transgenic mosquitoes, we assumed the transgenes are either dominate or recessive. We showed that transgenic mosquitoes can survive only if the total death-adjusted number of offspring with transgenes through heterogeneous matings exceeds that of offspring with no transgenes produced by wild mosquitoes, or there are too many wild offspring causing oscillations in the wild mosquito population. On the other hand, even if the transgenes are recessive, they can still drive wild mosquitoes to extinct. Therefore, dominate transgenes may not necessarily have advantage over recessive transgenes. In our models for interactive wild and paratransgenic mosquitoes, we assumed that the transmission of the genetically-modified bacteria can be vertically and horizontally. By our investigations, we found out that while the vertical transmission plays an important role in changing the wild mosquitoes to carrying transgenic bacteria, the horizontal transmission makes a clear picture that it can drive the wild mosquitoes to extinct. We worked on models for interactive wild and sterile mosquitoes more intensively in the last two years. The models were assumed to be either homogeneous or heterogeneous. We considered different strategies for the releases of sterile mosquitoes where the releases are constant, proportional to the size of wild mosquito population, or of Holling II type such that the releases are proportional to the size of wild mosquitos as the size is small, but saturated as the size is sufficiently large. We performed mathematical analysis and numerical simulations for these models. We derived explicit formulas for the threshold release values which determine whether wild mosquitoes can be eliminated. We found out that while the constant releases can lead wild mosquitoes to approaching zero more robustly, it has economic disadvantage that sterile mosquitoes are still released even the size of the wild mosquitoes is near zero. In contrast, the strategy with the releases proportional to the wild mosquito population size can lead both wild and sterile mosquitoes to approaching zero. Thus, it has economic advantage particularly when the wild mosquito population size is small. As a compromise, the strategy with the release function of the form of Holling-II type is able to gain the advantage of the constant releases but keep the releases more economically optimal. Our analysis shows that all dynamical features of the stage-structured models are kept. Thus these models will be used for the disease transmission models in our future investigations. Sponsored by this award, we also worked on the models with impulsive releases, where the releases are assumed periodical and impulsive. We considered either the releases are independent or dependent on the current abundance of wild or sterile mosquitoes such that sterile mosquitoes are not released until the size of the wild mosquitoes reaches a preset value or the amount of the sterile mosquitoes has dropped to a preset level. For the former case, the control measures for the releases are the amount of sterile mosquitoes released and the period of the impulsive releases, that is, the time interval between two releases. The wild mosquitoes can be wiped out or the two types of mosquitoes coexist based the thresholds determined from our model analysis. In the latter case, however, the goal is not to eradicate but reduce the wild mosquito size. This is more appropriate in the situation available resources are limited.
